topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny frames the episode as a practical GTM masterclass. Jeanne sets context: AI has intensified competition, so differentiation and GTM execution matter more than ever, and buyers often prioritize risk reduction over upside.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Datadog/Eppo (experimentation, analytics, feature flags), Lovable (AI app building), and Stripe (payments, billing, checkout).

topics.title: Defining go-to-market and its scope
topics.summary: Jeanne defines GTM as every function that touches customers or revenue (marketing, sales, CS, support, partnerships, technical sales). She argues GTM should be an integrated lifecycle rather than siloed Venn diagrams, and predicts role consolidation after years of hyper-specialization.

topics.title: What changed in GTM: consultative and embedded
topics.summary: Jeanne explains how consumption-based models and AI push GTM to be more consultative, helping customers navigate uncertainty and change. She highlights forward-deployed engineering as a way to embed with customers, learn, and feed insights back into product.

topics.title: Rise of the go-to-market engineer role
topics.summary: Jeanne recounts Stripe’s 2017 “company universe” outbound personalization attempt and why it was hard pre-AI. At Vercel, GTM engineers now build coded workflows/agents that replicate human steps to personalize outreach and other GTM tasks.

topics.title: Agents to increase seller time with customers
topics.summary: Jeanne broadens GTM engineering beyond outbound: agents can automate research, follow-up, and next-best-action across inbound, outbound, and install-base motions. The goal is shifting sellers from ~30–40% customer time toward ~70% by offloading rote work to agents.

topics.title: Human-in-the-loop outbound quality and safety
topics.summary: They discuss concerns about AI-generated spam and how Vercel keeps humans in the loop. Jeanne describes shadowing top performers to model workflows, letting agents draft decisions/messages, and having humans review/send while the system learns from edits and rejections.

topics.title: Impact: 10 SDRs to 1 via agents
topics.summary: Jeanne shares results: one GTM engineer built an inbound lead agent in ~6 weeks, enabling Vercel to reduce inbound SDR staffing from 10 to 1 while keeping lead-to-opportunity conversion flat and improving speed-to-response. The freed SDRs moved to outbound work.

topics.title: SDR and AE roles explained for newcomers
topics.summary: Jeanne defines SDRs as pipeline generators (inbound qualification and outbound prospecting) and AEs as closers who run the sales process to a paid decision. She explains increasing complexity from SMB to enterprise with more stakeholders and procurement.

topics.title: When to hire GTM engineering and first sales
topics.summary: Jeanne argues GTM engineering requires a documented, repeatable sales process, which many startups lack even at scale. She suggests earlier rigor (playbooks, content, discovery/objection handling) and notes founders should typically hire first sales around ~$1M ARR once ICP and repeatability exist.

topics.title: Ideal GTM engineer profile and Vercel advantage
topics.summary: Jeanne recommends GTM engineers with real GTM experience (often technical sales engineers) who understand sales best practices, not just code. She describes Vercel’s GTM engineers as former front-end devs using Vercel’s AI cloud to build and dogfood internal agents.

topics.title: GTM tools: Gong plus agent-driven deal coaching
topics.summary: Jeanne highlights Gong becoming more powerful when paired with agents: analyzing transcripts to find true loss reasons (e.g., missing economic buyer vs. price), then evolving into a real-time “deal-bot” that posts coaching insights into Slack channels. She also describes using agents to detect GTM “bugs” amid rapid product iteration and fix them via weekly sprints.

topics.title: Build vs buy: cheap, fast internal agents
topics.summary: Jeanne explains why building agents in-house can outperform buying point solutions: they’re quick to prototype (days to weeks) and extremely low-cost to run compared to headcount. She notes procurement friction and tool sprawl, predicting a shift toward internal platforms with many agents.

topics.title: How Vercel builds agents and GTM as product
topics.summary: Jeanne describes how Vercel’s team codes agents directly on Vercel (AI gateway, workflows, compute) and why dogfooding accelerates learning. She then introduces her long-held thesis: as software commoditizes, the buying journey and sales experience become key differentiators, motivating teams to design GTM like a product (e.g., Stripe’s architecture whiteboarding as discovery).
